content.title: Acquired Arteriovenous Fistula
content.definition: An acquired arteriovenous fistula (AVF) is an abnormal communication between an artery and vein resulting from trauma, surgery, or iatrogenic injury, allowing high-pressure arterial blood to shunt directly into the low-pressure venous system.

traumatic.penetrating: Stab wounds, gunshot wounds (most common cause)

pathologic.erosion: Aneurysm eroding into adjacent vein (aortocaval, iliac)

hemodynamics.shunt: Blood bypasses capillary bed, enters venous system directly
hemodynamics.high_output_state: May develop cardiac failure if large

progression.acute: May be silent or cause hemorrhage
progression.chronic: Fistula matures, vessels enlarge, symptoms develop

clinical_presentation.distal_ischemia: Steal phenomenon - cool, pale limb distally
clinical_presentation.cardiac: High-output heart failure if large, long-standing

aortocaval_fistula.presentation: Abdominal bruit, high-output failure, leg swelling

renal.presentation: Hematuria, hypertension, AV fistula on imaging

content.statement: Acquired Arteriovenous Fistula is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Arteriovenous-Fistula that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Acquired Arteriovenous Fistula include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Acquired Arteriovenous Fistula.

learning_objectives: Distinguish acquired from congenital arteriovenous fistula
Recognize clinical signs including Branham sign
Outline treatment options for acquired AVF
clinical_pearls: Continuous machinery murmur (not systolic-only) is characteristic
Branham sign: bradycardia with fistula compression indicates significant AVF
Large fistulas can cause high-output cardiac failure
Most iatrogenic femoral AVFs can be treated with covered stent
pedagogical.board_yield: MODERATE - important for trauma and access complications
